First, I'll comment on what I think you are asking in general... Later
I'll try and answer each question directly.

Personally, I like to write a test for each aspect of the thing I'm
testing. I really don't like copy and pasting tests with different test
data.

Let us say, for a given method there are 10 sets of parameters, or
corner cases, that completely cover that method.

If I were to follow the one test per set of parameters methodology, I
would need 10 tests to cover the method under test in question.

Now, I hate to say it, but for the sake of argument, the method under
test changes. (This happens to me a lot. I know a sign of lack of
think-first-driven development.) The result of the 10 tests each
different parameters is 10 test method changes for one method under test
change. To me that would lead to not wanting to write tests first.

On the other hand, supposed I supplied these 10 sets of parameters,
along with their expected output, to a parameterized Runner of the test
class. There would be only one test method for all of the sets of
parameters. Thus when the method under test changes, I need only to
change a single test method.

To address the running one set of data at a time. There is nothing
prohibiting someone from commenting out all of the other parameter sets
when you run the test class. Thus you allowed only the parameters you
wanted to run, to run. Basically performing the same task as running
one test method at a time.

Now for your direct questions...

[Pigneri, Rocco] but how is a parameterized test different from running
the same function over and over on different test data that is defined
in each test?

I think I discussed this above...

[Pigneri, Rocco] Does it run all the test functions on this single
parameterized instance and report on them as a group?

Please see lines 118-204 of the following link
http://github.com/bigmikef/junit/blob/f45b41bfc7699fb2cc031025e0eca71737
d9c88c/src/test/java/org/junit/tests/running/classes/ParameterizedTestTe
st.java

If you don't want to go there, I'll explain... (I think the two tests
really illustrate the point of a parameterized class.)

For each inner Object[] returned by the method annotated with
@Parameters, the entire test class is "tested". Each Object[] is passed
to the constructor of the test class. (These parameters might be
accessible other ways, but I haven't learned that yet.) Once your
constructor gets the parameters they can be used and referenced via
variables in the test methods. For that Object[] all the methods
annotated with @Test are executed.

My ide, eclipse, reports the results of each test as it happens just
like a standard test class. They are even grouped by index number of
the Object[] they used. Not really sure who is responsible for this
aspect.

[Pigneri, Rocco] Is parameterization simply a method of compacting code
and reporting by treating tests as parameterized groups rather than
independent functions exploded out to cover each parameterized case?

I think the answer is yes. But I might not understand the question.

Hope I helped,

Big Mike

P.S. Please annotate the original quote copied with something. It's
hard for me to realize that you are commenting on a previous statement.

instances of your test class, each with different parameters. (That you
supply.) What I want is to run a specific method after each run of a
parameterized instance of the "suite".

Interesting. I can take this conversation off-line if there is a
document somewhere that better explains this, but how is a parameterized
test different from running the same function over and over on different
test data that is defined in each test? Does it run all the test
functions on this single parameterized instance and report on them as a
group? Is parameterization simply a method of compacting code and
reporting by treating tests as parameterized groups rather than
independent functions exploded out to cover each parameterized case?

Well the problem is that @AfterClass runs after the entire class runs.
Not after each parameterized test.

A parameterized test performs like building a suite of multiple
instances of your test class, each with different parameters. (That you
supply.) What I want is to run a specific method after each run of a
parameterized instance of the "suite".

I've implemented a solution, and it is at
http://github.com/bigmikef/junit. It adds @BeforeParameterize and
@AfterParameterize to the Parameterized class. These methods are called
as expected during a Parameterized run.

It would be awesome if the owners included it in JUnit. I've already
requested a pull, but have not heard anything after that.

Thanks for the help,

Big Mike

Subject: [junit] Listening for after a parameterized instance run...

First, I'd like to say great group. I hope to respond to some questions
once I find one that I know the answer too.

On to my question,

Is there a way to listen to an event after a parameterized instance
runs?

What I'm doing might be better described with code...

@RunWith(Parameterized.class)

public class MyTest {

private static Map<String, Long> times = new HashMap<String, Long>();

public MyTest(Integer x, Integer y, Integer runs) {

this.x = x;

this.y = y;

this.runs = runs;

}

@Parameters

public static Collection permutations() {

return Arrays.asList(new Object[][] {

{1, 1, 1},

{1, 1, 10}

{1, 1, 100}

{1, 1, 1000},

.. . // vary x and y for each value of runs

});

}

@Test

public void useAlgX() {

//alg that uses x for runs number of runs

//add timing information to times

}

@Test

public void useAlgY() {

//alg that uses y for runs number of runs

//add timing information to times

}

@AfterParameterizedInstance

public void showParameterInsanceResults() {

//print time information in line for this run.

}

}

As you can see, I'd like to run both test methods with varying data,
changing the run times for each. This will generate a table of data
that I then can analyze and chart. The key thing I'd like to avoid is
using @After, and only print only after the tests have ran. (Doing
something like a boolean for each test, and a giant "and" statement VERY
BAD)

I'll be happy for any help you can render,

Big Mike
